  [Beginning of file MSS-ABCD, containing Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic 
   and Slovakia, and Denmark. These countries are in the file H-Z: 
   Australia, Canada]
  
  [revisions, additions, 1996: moved :NAnMu to :BAnMu]
  
  [Beginning of section A.MSS]
  (:AUSTRIA) :A
  (B Kreider `Austrian Graduals, Antiphoners ...' * MLA Notes *)
  
  (; BREGENZ)
  (P BREGENZ, Mehrerau Klosterarchiv)
  |:ABregM
  [:ABregM ms s.n.]   |.s.n.    |s1  ::ABregM
  [Miscellany] 2.misc
  [paper] 4.paper
  (u 14c) 14
  [this is in an elaborate German hand, and there may be opportunities for 
   dating] 4:G :G
       [inventory]
  [Kalendar] |s22
  K    (f.?) (Kr Thome episcopi et martyris) Thms;C
  [there follows what looks like an account book or register]
  [--]
  [from f.57 {?} is part of a square notation Antiphonal, with BVM.Pu, Palm 
   Sunday, Ascension, various stational processions, Good Friday, and Corpus 
   Christi, in very muddled arrangement]
       2.A 64.squ BVM.Pu XL.6 Asc XL.6.GF X.CX R=stations
  [--]
  [various leaves, some from a Noted Breviary with partly heighted neumes, 
   others from Breviaries and Graduals]
       2.B.noted 2.NB 64.neumes.heighted
  [--]
  [various leaves from an Antiphonal, with square notation, Holy Week, Easter 
   Week to Tri, and the summer historie]
  [other information] |s31
  3.HMML [29893] 3
  [EndRec]

  [Offices, noted] 2.Off.noted 2.NOff
  [Offices, Masses and sequences] =Q* E=
  (i lavishly illuminated with whole-page pictures, not necessarily on the 
   folio cited)
  (f no foliation is visible on the film: the roman numbers below are taken 
   from the index. The Arabic numbers are mine, from inspection, counting 
   from 1)
  [the arrangement is very confusing, and needs a thorough study]
       [inventory]
  [the general order seems to be that of offices, with chant and lessons, 
   then the Mass, then legenda, vitas, poems, rhythmi, metra, &c] rithmus 
   metrum
  (r ... in ingressu templi sancti gereonis ... coloniensi) :GC (f.1)

  (B not in Bannister-James cat. but see p.190)

   feasts without music] $=
  (K 0804) [added:] (r hoc die fuit bellum de Evesham anno di' møccølxø 
   quinto) (f.185v)
  (K added obit of Bp. Peter de Aqua Blanca, Nov. 27, 1268, in original hand 
   {?}, but that of his successor, John de Breton, consecr. 1269, died 1275, 
   is not: therefore 1269-75: but 1254-8 because Henry Bustard is not in 
   obits {then Peter de AB must have been added later}; no Edmund;C, can. 
   1246.7) 1269-75? 1254-8? 13

  (B pamphlet compiled by Conservation Committee of the parish)
  [Adv.1 is Sarum, also Adv.2, LXX, LX, and L, rather than York]
  [written in early 15c, owned by Wm Husse, rector of $Leonard's, Woll., died 
   1448-1460, who left money for its purchase for the benefit of W. Church. 
   Lost and discovered later in drawer in Wollaton Hall {badly damaged by 
   fire in 1642. The new hall, the present one, finished in 1588}. Restored 
   to church by Lord Middleton in 1924]
  [arms on many pages] heraldry

  |:ECU
  [additional manuscripts, with numerals, are listed before the LL.vi.45 type 
   call numbers]
  [some authorities cite the second element of the double-letter call numbers 
   in Roman figures. The * Catalogue of MSS: Subject Index * cites them in 
   Arabic]
  [Psalters not listed here comprehensively: only if Sarum or otherwise 
   interesting]
  
  [:ECU misc.mss]     |.misc.mss     |s1  ::ECU
  [there are three big sections here: 1} mss listed by call number only 
   {mostly Psalters, Pontificals, etc.}; 2} mss briefly listed, with some 
   information; and 3} mss that are inventoried more or less completely:]
  [--]
  [1: references only]
  [Psalters: add. 851, 2590, 3169, 3204, 4082, 4085, 4090, 4110, 4111 {OP, 
   with notes}, 7220, and Dd.i.5, Dd.i.20, Dd.iv.25, Dd.iv.39, Dd.v.2, 

   Kk.iv.23, Kk.vi.21, Kk.vi.45, Ll.ii.10, Mm.i.15, Mm.iii.10]

   3204, 3208, 3322, 3474, 3475, 4113, 4450, 4500, 6668, 8898, and Dd.v.5, 

  [Psalters, Breviaries, fragments, various, some with music] 2.fragments
            (ms add. 2697)

   which are empty!}. Mostly seem to have been removed from bindings]

       (f.B) 2.P
  [numerous small bits and pieces, unnumbered: those that are too small or 
   likely to be unproductive, are only listed]

  [none with any significant music]
            (ms add. 2710, 2710A)

   complete] 2.B
       Geremarus .t [all from the Common]

  [:ECU add.4113]     |.4113    |s1  ::ECU
  (s Antiphonale {Psalter}, supplement, 16c) 16
  [Officia: not a Psalter! 16c seems reasonable] 2.Off
  [monastic, 82ff, 10.5x14.5 inches] 5.mon
       X.CX (f.1)
       [Mass] E= (f.38, ending on f.41)
       (f.41v blank: for 42 and 42v see following note)
  [gatherings: A.8 B.8 C.8 D.8 E.10 The last page of the quaternion that is 
   internal to this gathering is blank, as though it were intended as the 
   true last page. Leaf 42 and 42v are * exact * duplicates {except for the 
   colour of the size 2 initials}, lacking the chant, of 8 and 8v, hence the 
   cue to Verbum. But this leaf is part of a bifolium with 33, which is in 
   the correct place. Since 42 and 42v are an exact duplicate it looks as 
   though the intention was to have * exactly * paired books, one for each 
   side of the choir. Somehow, 42 and 42v, were not finished, and its 
   bifolium partner, 33 and 33v, being blank, accidentally or even 
   deliberately came to be used as the first leaf of the final gathering. 
   This does not quite make sense, and the situation seems inexplicable.]
  [different hand]
       BVM.V! @r [seems to be a mixture of the Visitation and Presentation 
   offices] 3.slide (f.43)
       [Mass] E= (f.69)
       X.$C.E (f.71)
  [information]
       4.paleog [details on ruling, design etc., in Cambridge notebook]
  3 3.AH 3.film [199 CPX: slide of f.43]
  [EndRec]

  [:ELR ms Cust.1]    |.Cust.1  |s1  ::ELR
  [Liber de antiquis legibus] 2.Liber
  (u ca.1270) 1270.ca 13
       [inventory]
  [contains a chronicle of the mayors, sheriffs, and bishops of London, and 
   archbishops of Canterbury, 1189-1274, and other historical matter. 
   Opinions differ as to whether ff.160v-62v were part of the original or 
   added] :EL
       [misc.] (flyleaves and ff.1-159v)

  [Vita] 2.Vita
  [Vita and other material relating to Mildred, Mildretha]
  [1091, for Canterbury, $Augustine's] 11 1091 for:ECa$A
       [inventory]

            [historia partly structured]
            [an independent libellus with 8 leaves]
       [translation: textus and instruccionis] (f.51)
  [--]
  [Vita, and surely the rest, composed by Goscelin, precentor of Canterbury, 
   1091-5: snippets of the historia are to be found quoted elsewhere in 
   Goscelin's works.] &Goscelin
  [carefully noted: clefs placed in anticipation of next item] 64.clefs!
  64.squ [slender square notation]
  [on four dry-point lines with ragged ends] 64.stave!
  4.dry-p [text line also in dry-point extending to edge of page]
  [other information] |s21

  (; BERLIN)
  (P BERLIN, Preussische Staatsbibliothek: Staatsbibliothek zu 
   Berlin-Preussischer Kulturbesitz)
  (B Kristeller: divided into two parts; reunited in 1989)
  |:GBP
  [Churfrstliche Bibl. later the K”nigliche Bibl. in 1918 became the 
   Preussische Bibl. After May 1946 the collection was scattered: some was 
   lost, or destroyed, some went to the Russian zone, some to the Deutsche 
   Staatsbibl {™ffentliche Wissenschaftliche Bibl. 1946-54}. More than half 
   went to the Staatsbibl. der Stiftung Preussischer Kulturbesitz {Marburg 
   is Hessische Bibl. 1946-49, Westdeutsche Bibl. 1949-62} {info. from Isham 
   card}]

  [`According to Mr Heinemann, a dealer in old books from whom I purchased 
   this volume in 1965 it was written in Italy somewhere between 1460 and 
   1480. I suspect that it was intended for use in Germany, as there are 
   responsories and antiphons proper to the feasts of certain German saints. 
   The book contains more responsories than antiphons.'] wr:I? 4:I

  [    e-cedilla î ASC238]
  [    n-acute ü ASC252]

   ms s.n., and begins with ms 2 !]

   from Pikulik's references in * Etat *. Then Feicht's Miechovite 

   with s.n.} !]

  |:IFC
  (secondary references only: keywords not verified)
  (s Marica S. Tacconi:) [Originally, the museum owned 58 manuscripts, 
   covering the entire liturgical years, not just for daily use but for 
   special religious occasions. These included Antiphonaries, Graduals, and 
   Evangeliaries. Three of these manuscripts were saved from the 1966 flood. 
   One more has been restored. See: Preti pp.34-7]
  (B Preti, Monica, ed. Museum of thc Opera del Duomo of Florence {Milan: 
   Electa, 1989})

  |:IFN_Banco.Rari
  [:IFN Banco Rari 18 {II.I.122}]    |.18 |s1  ::IFN
  [Laudario della Compagnia di Santo Spirito] 2.Laudario
  (u 14c)
  (p: Compagnia di Santo Spirito {Chiesa degli Agostiniani, Florence}) 
   from:IF$Sp 14 5.OSA

   before 1321) 5.OP 1321>
  [these ms numbers do not identify 14 books !!]
  [in addition to these 14 volumes, there are others, also apparently 
   Dominican, and apparently in the same series of call numbers: 2791, 2797, 
   2798: it is not clear whether the books with the numbers not mentioned 
   still exist.]
  [without access to the books themselves, it is not possible accurately to 
   place the books in the proper sequence: the following table sets out the 
   possible order, assuming that the 14 books grouped together in Fd'A {here 
   marked with an asterisk} are in fact correctly organized:]
  [    2781 *    no information]
  [    2782 *    LXX to XL.2         #3 in sequence]
  [    2783 *    Adv to Nat          #1 in sequence]
  [    2784 *    no information]
  [    2785 *    Tri.1 to 18         #7 in sequence]

  [    2792      no information]

  [    2799 *    no information]
       [Thms.A added to 2799] Thms.A+
  [    2800 *    no information]

   necessary to complete the whole liturgical year. Possibly there are books 

  |:ISP
  
  [:ISP Chorali] |.Chorali |s1  ::ISP
  [this information derives from viewing the books in the display cases, 
   supplemented from Carli. Folio numbers were often hidden.]
  [all are 30x42 inches: large!] 2.Choirbook
  [all 15c] 15
  [all illuminated: normally displayed books are open at good pages] 4.illum
  [the indexed names that follow are those of the illuminators, named in the 
   descriptions {often in more than one ms}:] artist
            &Liberale.da.V &Girolamo.da.C &Pellegrino.di.M 
   &Giovanni.da.U &Guidoccio.Cozz &Benvenuto.di.G &.Benedetti.di.P 
   &Bernardino.Cignoni &Venturino.da.M &Francesco.Rosselli &Sano.di.P 
   &Giovanni.da.F &Giacomo.di.F.T &.Mariano.Antonio.da.S
  [--]
  [Antiphonals seem to be numbered sequentially with a number.letter]
  [Graduals seems to be numbered sequentially {continuing from the 
   Antiphonals ?}, with a number.number]
  [--]
  [Carli and a plate or page number denotes information from Enzo Carli]
